data.title: Fall TV 2018: First Look Photos at All the New Broadcast Dramas and Comedies
data.meta_description: Is one of the following new series the next 'This Is Us' or 'Big Bang Theory'? THR rounds up all the photos from the broadcasters' 2018-19 slate.
data.text:
‘Charmed’ (The CW)

The reboot is described as a fierce, funny and feminist take on the original series and centers on three sisters (Melonie Diaz, Sarah Jeffery and Madeleine Mantock) in a college town who discover they are witches. Between vanquishing supernatural demons, tearing down the patriarchy, and maintaining familial bonds, a witch's work is never done. The drama hails from the CBS Television Studios-based team behind Jane the Virgin Jessica O'Toole, Amy Rardin and Jennie Urman.

‘Legacies’ (The CW)

This spinoff of The Originals sees Matt Davis — who started with The Vampire Diaries — starring alongside Danielle Rose Russell in a drama about a teenage Hope that is set in Mystic Falls at the Salvatore Boarding School for the Young and Gifted. The drama, which did not produce a typical pilot, hails from Julie Plec and co-writer Brett Matthews. The order keeps the franchise going at The CW, which this season is saying farewell to The Originals (after five seasons) and last year parted ways with The Vampire Diaries (after eight seasons).

‘All American’ (The CW)

From exec producer Greg Berlanti and writer April Blair, the drama revolves around a high school football player (Daniel Ezra) from South Central L.A. who is recruited to play for Beverly Hills High and the wins, losses and struggles of two families from different worlds. Based on the life of pro football player Spencer Paysinger, the series has been described as Friday Night Lights meets Straight Outta Compton. Taye Diggs co-stars in the Warner Bros. TV drama.

‘A Million Little Things’ (ABC)

A Million Little Things, from writer and executive producer DJ Nash, centers on a group of friends reeling from a recent and sudden loss. The cast includes David Giuntoli as Eddie, Ron Livingston as Jon, Romany Malco as Rome, Allison Miller as Maggie, Christina Moses as Regina, Christina Ochoa as Ashley, James Roday as Gary, Stephanie Szostak as Delilah and Lizzy Greene as Sophie.

‘A Million Little Things’ (ABC)

They say friendship isn't one big thing, it's a million little things; and that's true for a group of friends from Boston who bonded under unexpected circumstances. Some have achieved success, others are struggling in their careers and relationships, but all of them feel stuck in life. After one of them dies unexpectedly, it's just the wake-up call the others need to finally start living. Along the way they discover that friends may be the one thing to save them from themselves.

‘A Million Little Things’ (ABC)

David Giuntoli, Romany Malco and Christina Moses are among the show's series regulars.

‘A Million Little Things’ (ABC)

James Roday plays Gary and Allison Miller plays Maggie in A Million Little Things.

‘A Million Little Things’ (ABC)

David Giuntoli, James Roday and Romany Malco star as members of a friend group who are bonded together over unexpected circumstances.

‘A Million Little Things’ (ABC)

When one of the friends dies unexpectedly, the group realizes it's time to finally start living. Stephanie Szostak, Christina Moses and Allison Miller are among the cast members of the new ABC drama.

‘Grand Hotel’ (ABC)

Demian Bichir and Roselyn Sanchez star as Santiago and Gigi Mendoza, owners of the last family-owned hotel in multicultural Miami Beach. Eva Longoria executive produces along with writer and executive producer Brian Tanen.

‘Grand Hotel’ (ABC)

Charismatic Santiago Mendoza owns the titular hotel, while his glamorous second wife, Gigi, and their adult children enjoy the spoils of success.

‘Grand Hotel’ (ABC)

The drama revolves around Santiago and Gigi as well as their adult children, the hotel's wealthy guests, scandals, secrets and escalating debt.

‘Grand Hotel’ (ABC)

Devious Maids alum Brian Tanen penned the script and exec produces the ABC Studios drama alongside Eva Longoria.

‘Grand Hotel’ (ABC)

The show is based on the Spanish TV series Gran Hotel from Carlos Sedes and starring Yon Gonzalez and Amaia Salamanca. It ran from 2011 through 2013 for a total of three seasons.

‘Single Parents’

From creators and executive producers JJ Philbin and Liz Meriwether, the new ABC comedy follows a group of single parents as they lean on each other to help raise their 7-year-old kids and maintain some kind of personal lives outside of parenthood.

‘Single Parents’ (ABC)

The series begins when the group meets Will, a 30-something guy who’s been so focused on raising his daughter that he’s lost sight of who he is as a man.

‘Single Parents’ (ABC)

When the other single parents see just how far down the rabbit hole of PTA, parenting and princesses Will has gone, they band together to get him out in the dating world and make him realize that being a great parent doesn’t mean sacrificing everything about your own identity.

‘Single Parents’ (ABC)

Single Parents stars Taran Killam as Will, Leighton Meester as Angie, Kimrie Lewis as Poppy, Jake Choi as Miggy, Marlow Barkley as Sophie, Tyler Wladis as Graham, Devin Trey Campbell as Rory, Grace Hazelett as Emma, Sadie Hazelett as Amy and Brad Garrett as Douglas.

‘The Fix’ (ABC)

Attorney and author Marcia Clark co-writes and executive produces a new legal drama about Maya Travis (Robin Tunney), an L.A. district attorney who suffers a devastating defeat when prosecuting an A-list actor for double murder.

‘The Fix’ (ABC)

With her high-profile career derailed, Maya flees for a quieter life in Washington. Eight years later when this same celebrity is under suspicion for another murder, she's lured back to the DA’s office for another chance at justice.

‘The Fix’ (ABC)

The cast of The Fix includes Adam Rayner as Matthew Collier, Merrin Dungey as CJ, Breckin Meyer as Alan Wiest, Marc Blucas as Riv, and Mouzam Makkar as Loni.

‘The Fix’ (ABC)

In addition to Marcia Clark, the prosecutor best known for her work on the O.J. Simpson murder trial, The Fix is executive produced by Elizabeth Craft & Sarah Fain.

‘The Kids Are Alright’ (ABC)

Set in the 1970s, this ensemble comedy follows a traditional Irish-Catholic family, the Clearys, as they navigate big and small changes during one of America’s most turbulent decades.

‘The Kids Are Alright’ (ABC)

In a working-class neighborhood outside Los Angeles, Mike and Peggy raise eight boisterous boys who live out their days with little supervision. The household is turned upside down when oldest son Lawrence returns home and announces he’s quitting the seminary to go off and “save the world.” Times are changing and this family will never be the same. There are 10 people, three bedrooms, one bathroom and everyone in it for themselves.

‘The Kids Are Alright’ (ABC)

The series is inspired by the childhood of writer/executive producer Tim Doyle, and stars Michael Cudlitz as Mike Cleary, Mary McCormack as Peggy Cleary, Sam Straley as Lawrence, Caleb Martin Foote as Eddie, Sawyer Barth as Frank Christopher Paul Richards as Joey, Jack Gore as Timmy, Andy Walken as William and Santino Barnard as Pat.

‘Whiskey Cavalier’ (ABC)

Scott Foley and Lauren Cohan star in the new ABC thriller about an FBI agent and CIA operative who lead an inter-agency team on high-octane missions. Ana Ortiz, Tyler James Williams and Edgar Standish also star, while Dave Hemingson serves as writer and executive producer.

‘Schooled’ (ABC)

From Marc Firek and Adam F. Goldberg, Schooled is the straight-to-series spinoff of The Goldbergs, set in 1990-something and focused on the hilarious teachers of William Penn Academy – led by Tim Meadows (Principal Glascott), Bryan Callen (Coach Mellor) and AJ Michalka (Lainey Lewis) – who, despite their eccentricities and crazy personal lives, are heroes to their students.

‘The Rookie’ (ABC)

Written and executive produced by Alexi Hawley, The Rookie stars Nathan Fillion as John Nolan, a man pursuing his dream of being an LAPD officer after a life-altering incident. As the force’s oldest rookie, he’s met with skepticism from some higher-ups who see him as just a walking midlife crisis. If he can’t keep up with the young cops and the criminals, he’ll be risking lives including his own. But if he can use his life experience, determination and sense of humor to give him an edge, he may just become a success in this new chapter of his life. In addition to Fillion, The Rookie features Alyssa Diaz as Angela Lopez, Richard T. Jones as Sergeant Wade Grey, Titus Makin as Jackson West, Mercedes Mason as Captain Zoe Andersen, Melissa O’Neil as Lucy Chen, Afton Williamson as Talia Bishop and Eric Winter as Tim Bradford. Mark Gordon, Fillion, Michelle Chapman and Jon Steinberg are executive producers on the series.

‘Magnum P.I.’ (CBS)

Jay Hernandez stars in the Hawaii-set "updated" reboot of the Tom Selleck classic as an ex-Navy SEAL who returns home from Afghanistan and repurposes his military skills to become a private investigator. Hawaii Five-0 and MacGyver boss Peter Lenkov will serve as showrunner on the drama from Eric Guggenheim and The Blacklist duo John Davis and John Fox. The series is a co-production between CBS Television Studios and Universal Television.

‘FAM’ (CBS)

Nina Dobrev and Tone Bell star in this comedy about a woman whose vision of a perfect life with her adoring fiancé and his wonderful family is radically altered when her 16-year old, out-of-control half-sister unexpectedly comes to live with her.

‘FBI’ (CBS)

Dick Wolf and the team behind the Law & Order franchise are responsible for FBI, a fast-paced drama about the inner workings of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The cast includes Missy Peregrym and Zeeko Zaki as special agents Maggie Bell and Omar Adom 'OA' Zidan, who bring their expertise together to keep New York and the country safe.

‘Welcome to the Neighborhood’ (CBS)

The multicamera comedy from Big Bang Theory writer Jim Reynolds revolves around the nicest guy in the Midwest who moves his family into a tough neighborhood in L.A. where not everyone appreciates his extreme neighborliness. Cedric the Entertainer, Josh Lawson, Tichina Arnold and Dreama Walker star in the CBS Television Studios series from Aaron Kaplan's Kapital Entertainment.

‘Murphy Brown’ (CBS)

The landmark sitcom will return to CBS with a 13-episode straight-to-series order. Candice Bergen will reprise her iconic role as the famous newscaster, with creator Diane English also returning as writer and executive producer through her Bend in the Road Productions shingle.

‘REL’ (Fox)

From writer, executive producer and star Lil Rel Howery, REL is inspired by the multi-hyphenate's own life. The series focuses on Lil Rel, a prideful, self-made success who lives by the code to "always believe in yourself and great things will come." He finds that attitude put to the test when he learns his wife is having an affair with his own barber. He tries to rebuild his life post-divorce as a long-distance single father on the South Side of Chicago who's on a quest for love, respect and a new barber. Sinbad, Jess "Hilarious" Moore and Jordan L. Jones also star.

‘The Passage’ (FOX)

From writer and executive producer Elizabeth Heldens, and based on author Justin Cronin's trilogy of the same name, The Passage focuses on a secret government medical facility experimenting with a dangerous virus that could either cure all disease or cause the downfall of the human race. The series stars Mark?Paul Gosselaar, Saniyya Sidney, Vincent Piazza, Brianne Howey, Jamie McShane, Caroline Chikezie and Emmanuelle Chriqui.

‘Proven Innocent’ (Fox)

A legal drama from Danny Strong Productions in association with 20th Century Fox Television, Proven Innocent stars Rachelle Lefevre as Madeline Scott, a fearless lawyer with a hunger for justice whose team reopens investigations, putting their own lives in danger to exonerate the innocent that were "proven" guilty. Russell Hornsby, Nikki M. James, Vincent Kartheiser, Riley Smith and Clare O’Connor also star, with executive producers including David Elliot, Danny Strong and Stacy Greenberg.

‘Last Man Standing’ (FOX)

Tim Allen's multicamera comedy from 20th TV has officially been revived for a seventh season a year after being canceled at ABC. Allen has signed on and has been — with producers 20th Century Fox Television — the driving force behind the revival. Stars Nancy Travis, Jonathan Adams, Amanda Fuller, Christoph Sanders and Jordan Masterson have also locked in deals to return.

‘The Cool Kids’ (Fox)

From executive producer and showrunner Kevin Abbott, as well as executive producers Charlie Day and Nick Frenkel, The Cool Kids centers on three guy friends in a retirement community who are the top dogs until they’re blown out of the water by the newest member of the community, a female rebel whose ready to challenge their place. Described as "high school with 70 somethings," the cast of The Cool Kids includes Vicki Lawrence, Martin Mull, David Alan Grier, and Leslie Jordan.

‘The Inbetween’ (NBC)

Harriet Dyer, Anne-Marie Johnson, Cindy Luna, Chad James Buchanan and Paul Blackthorne star in this NBC series from writer and executive producer Moira Kirland of Castle and Madam Secretary fame. The drama focuses on Dyer as Cassie Bishop, a woman who can see and communicate with the dead, helping them with their unresolved problems, whether she likes it or not. She teams together with a detective and an FBI agent to help them solve a darkly puzzling murder, using her abilities. Despite her reluctance, she may have found a way to keep her demons at bay, all while solving some of the city’s most challenging cases.

‘Manifest’ (NBC)

From Robert Zemeckis and Jack Rapke, Manifest is described as an "emotionally rich, unexpected journey into a world grounded in hope, heart and destiny." When Montego Air Flight 828 landed safely after a turbulent but routine flight, the crew and passengers were relieved. Yet in the span of those few hours, the world had aged five years and their friends, families and colleagues, after mourning their loss, had given up hope and moved on. Now, faced with the impossible, they’re all given a second chance. But as their new realities become clear, a deeper mystery unfolds and some of the returned passengers soon realize they may be meant for something greater than they ever thought possible. Melissa Roxburgh, Josh Dallas, Athena Karkanis, J.R. Ramirez, Luna Blaise, Jack Messina and Parveen Kaur star in the series.

‘I Feel Bad’ (NBC)

Sarayu Blue, Paul Adelstein, Aisling Bea, Zach Cherry, Johnny Pemberton and James Buckley star in the comedy about being perfectly OK with being imperfect, from writer and executive producer Aseem Batra. From NBC: "Emet is the perfect mom, boss, wife, friend and daughter. OK, she’s not perfect. In fact, she’s just figuring it out like the rest of us. Sure, she feels bad when she has a sexy dream about someone other than her husband, or when she pretends not to know her kids when they misbehave in public, or when she uses her staff to help solve personal problems. But that’s OK, right? Nobody can have it all and do it perfectly."

‘Abby’s’ (NBC)

From the producers of The Good Place, the new NBC comedy starring Natalie Morales (Parks & Recreation) takes place in a San Diego bar where cell phones are outlawed and oddball regulars are ever present. Nelson Franklin, Kimia Behpoornia, Jessica Chaffin, Leonard Ouzts and Neil Flynn also star in the comedy from writer and executive producer Josh Malmuth.

‘New Amsterdam’ (NBC)

The network's first pilot-to-series order of the season, medical drama New Amsterdam follows Dr. Max Goodwin (played by The Blacklist alum Ryan Eggold), a medical director who sets out to tear up the bureaucracy and provide exceptional care. Goodwin must disrupt the status quo and prove he will stop at nothing to breathe new life into this understaffed, underfunded and underappreciated facility — the only one in the world capable of treating Ebola patients, prisoners from Rikers Island and the President of the United States under one roof — and return it to the glory that put it on the map. David Schulner and Peter Horton are executive producers, with Schulner serving as showrunner. The drama also stars Janet Montgomery, Tyler Labine, Jocko Sims, Freema Agyeman and Anupam Kher.

‘The Enemy Within’ (NBC)

Jennifer Carpenter stars as Erica Shepherd, a brilliant former CIA operative, now known as the most notorious traitor in American history serving life in a Supermax prison, who teams up with FBI agent Will Keaton (Morris Chestnut) to track down an elusive criminal. Raza Jaffrey and Kelli Garner also star. Ken Woodruff executive produces and writes.

‘The Village’ (NBC)

From NBC, The Village centers on "an apartment building in Brooklyn that appears like any other from the outside but is quite unique inside. The people who reside here have built a bonded family of friends and neighbors. Sarah’s a nurse and single mom raising a creative teen; Gabe’s a young law student who got a much older and unexpected roommate; Ava must secure the future of her young, U.S.-born son when ICE comes knocking; Nick’s a veteran who’s returned from war; and the heart and soul of the building, Ron and Patricia, have captivating tales all their own. These are the hopeful, heartwarming and challenging stories of life that prove family is everything — even if it’s the one you make with the people around you."

‘The Village’ (NBC)

Mike Daniels will write and executive produce. Minkie Spiro will direct and executive produce the pilot. Jessica Rhoades also executive produces.

‘The Village’ (NBC)

The cast includes Moran Atias, Dominic Chianese, Warren Christie, Frankie Faison, Jerod Haynes, Daren Kagasoff, Michaela McManus, Lorraine Toussaint and Grace Van Dien.

tk

‘The Goldbergs’ Spinoff (ABC)

ABC is expanding the world of The Goldbergs, handing out a 13-episode series order for the 1990s-set spinoff formerly known as Schooled. Former Goldbergs series regular AJ Michalka, who plays Barry's (Troy Gentile) ex-girlfriend, Lainey, has joined the cast of the untitled project. Goldbergs creators Adam F. Goldberg and Marc Firek are executive producing alongside Doug Robinson, with the series set to follow the teachers of William Penn Academy — led by Tim Meadows' Principal Glascott, Bryan Callen's Coach Mellor and Michalka's Lainey Lewis — who, despite their eccentricities and crazy personal lives, are heroes to their students.
